title: Core Certificate Engine
description: Core cryptographic logic for ShushTLS. Generate a self-signed root CA, issue wildcard leaf certificates signed by that CA, persist all material to disk, and reload on startup. No HTTP concerns — this is the pure certificate engine layer.

title: Define certificate parameters and defaults
description: Define all cryptographic parameters: key algorithms (e.g. ECDSA P-256 or RSA 2048+), root CA validity (20-30 years), leaf validity (10+ years), wildcard SAN pattern (*.home.arpa), key usages, extended key usages, serial number generation strategy. These are constants/config the rest of the engine depends on.

title: Implement root CA generation
description: Implement self-signed root CA generation. Generate a private key and self-signed X.509 certificate with CA:TRUE, appropriate key usages (certSign, crlSign), and the configured long validity period. Return the key pair and certificate as in-memory objects (no disk I/O in this layer).

title: Implement wildcard leaf certificate issuance
description: Implement leaf certificate generation signed by the root CA. Generate a new key pair, create a certificate with the wildcard SAN (e.g. *.home.arpa), appropriate key usages (digitalSignature, keyEncipherment), extended key usage (serverAuth), and the configured validity. The issuing CA key and cert are inputs.

title: Persist keys and certificates to disk
description: Implement PEM encoding and disk persistence for all cryptographic material: root CA key, root CA cert, leaf key, leaf cert. Define a clear on-disk layout. Use safe file writing (write-then-rename or restrictive permissions on keys). Private keys should be written with 0600 permissions.

title: Load existing material on startup
description: Implement loading of existing root CA and leaf certificates from disk on startup. Parse PEM files, validate that loaded material is well-formed (valid x509, key matches cert). Return structured state indicating what exists and what is missing.

title: Enforce idempotent behavior
description: Ensure the certificate engine never accidentally regenerates existing material. If a root CA already exists on disk, generation must be a no-op or an explicit error. Same for leaf certificates. Idempotency prevents catastrophic trust breakage if the service restarts or the user double-clicks initialize.

title: Application Bootstrapping Logic
description: Bootstrap logic that detects first-run vs initialized state and enforces the correct serving mode. HTTP-only before root CA exists, HTTPS-only after. Prevents TLS deadlocks and invalid mixed states. Defines restart requirements.

title: Detect first-run vs initialized state
description: Implement state detection logic: check disk for root CA material. Define a clear enum/type for system state (Uninitialized, Initialized, Ready). Uninitialized = no root CA. Initialized = root CA exists but no leaf cert for ShushTLS itself. Ready = all material present for HTTPS serving.

title: Enforce HTTP-only mode before initialization
description: When state is Uninitialized, the service must only listen on HTTP. The HTTP server serves the setup UI and API endpoints for initialization. No TLS listener should be created. This is the entry point for first-time users.

title: Enforce HTTPS-only mode after initialization
description: When state is Ready (root CA + ShushTLS leaf cert exist), the service must only listen on HTTPS using the ShushTLS leaf certificate. The leaf cert must be signed by the root CA, not self-signed. HTTP should either redirect to HTTPS or not be served at all.

title: Prevent invalid mixed states
description: Add defensive checks: never serve HTTPS without valid certs, never serve HTTP after initialization is complete. Handle edge cases like partial initialization (root CA exists but leaf does not) gracefully — either complete the setup or present clear guidance.

title: Define restart requirements clearly
description: After initialization completes (root CA + leaf cert generated), the user must restart ShushTLS to switch from HTTP to HTTPS mode. The UI and API must clearly communicate this requirement. Consider whether a graceful self-restart is feasible or if manual restart is the right UX.

title: HTTP API
description: Machine- and script-friendly HTTP API layer. JSON responses, idempotent operations, scriptable via curl. No authentication (LAN trust model). The API is first-class — the Web UI is a consumer of this API, not a replacement for it.

title: Define API surface and semantics
description: Design the full API contract: endpoints, HTTP methods, request/response shapes, status codes, error format. Key endpoints: POST /api/initialize, GET /api/status, GET /api/ca/root.pem (download root CA), POST /api/certificates/wildcard, GET /api/certificates/wildcard (download). Document idempotency guarantees.

title: Implement initialization endpoint
description: POST /api/initialize — triggers root CA generation and ShushTLS leaf cert generation. Must be idempotent: if already initialized, return success with current state. Returns JSON with status and next steps (e.g. install root CA, restart). Must refuse to run if already in HTTPS mode.

title: Implement root CA download endpoint
description: GET /api/ca/root.pem — serves the root CA certificate as a PEM file download. Must set appropriate Content-Type and Content-Disposition headers. Must return 404 or appropriate error if root CA does not exist yet.

title: Implement wildcard certificate generation endpoint
description: POST /api/certificates/wildcard — generate a wildcard leaf certificate signed by the root CA for the configured domain (e.g. *.home.arpa). Accepts domain as parameter. Idempotent if a wildcard cert for that domain already exists. Returns JSON with certificate details.

title: Implement status/introspection endpoint
description: GET /api/status — returns JSON describing the current system state: whether root CA exists, its fingerprint and expiry, whether leaf certs exist, current serving mode (HTTP/HTTPS), configured domain. This is the heartbeat endpoint for scripts and the UI.

title: Ensure API is usable without the UI
description: Verify and document that the full initialization and certificate workflow can be completed entirely via curl or similar tools. Provide example curl commands. The API must not depend on browser sessions, cookies, or UI-specific state.

title: Web UI (Pico.css)
description: Human-friendly web interface using server-rendered HTML and Pico.css. No SPA framework, no frontend build toolchain. Minimal JavaScript only for calling the API. The UI is a thin client that delegates all business logic to the API layer. Designed for clarity and discoverability years after setup.

title: Define UI structure and navigation
description: Design the page structure: landing/status page, setup wizard flow, trust installation pages, certificate management page. Define navigation (simple top nav or sidebar). Keep it minimal — Pico.css semantic HTML. No complex routing needed since this is server-rendered.

title: Implement first-run setup page
description: The page shown when ShushTLS is uninitialized. Explains what ShushTLS does, provides a clear 'Initialize' button that calls POST /api/initialize, shows progress/result, then guides the user to install the root CA and restart. Must work without JavaScript for the explanation, JS only for the API call.

title: Implement trust installation guidance pages
description: Pages with platform-specific instructions for installing the root CA. Each platform (Linux, macOS, Windows, iOS, Android) gets its own section or page. Includes a prominent download button/link for the root CA PEM file (calls GET /api/ca/root.pem). Instructions must be copy-pasteable.

title: Implement certificate status display
description: A dashboard/status page that shows: root CA existence, fingerprint, and expiry; wildcard cert existence, domain, and expiry; current serving mode; system health. Calls GET /api/status and renders the results. This is the main page after initialization.

title: Implement API-backed actions via minimal JS
description: Write minimal vanilla JavaScript to call the API for actions like initialize, generate wildcard cert. Use fetch(), handle errors gracefully, update the page with results. No frameworks, no build step. JS should be inline or a single small embedded file.

title: Ensure UI degrades gracefully without JS
description: All informational content (status, instructions, documentation) must be readable without JavaScript. Only interactive actions (initialize, generate) require JS. If JS is disabled, show a clear message explaining that actions require JavaScript. No blank pages.

title: Platform Trust HOWTOs
description: Clear, copy-pasteable trust installation instructions for every supported platform. ShushTLS must NOT auto-install trust — only provide guidance. Each platform gets its own documentation with commands, screenshots descriptions, and caveats.

title: Linux trust installation instructions
description: Debian/Ubuntu style: copy PEM to /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/, run update-ca-certificates. Include commands for verifying installation. Note that this covers system trust only — some apps (Firefox, Java) have their own stores.

title: macOS trust installation instructions
description: Instructions using security add-trusted-cert or Keychain Access GUI. Cover both command-line and GUI approaches. Note that the cert must be set to 'Always Trust' for SSL.

title: Windows trust installation instructions
description: Instructions using certutil or the MMC certificates snap-in. Install into Trusted Root Certification Authorities store for the Local Machine. Cover both PowerShell/cmd and GUI approaches.

title: iOS trust installation instructions
description: Instructions for downloading the profile via Safari, installing via Settings > General > Profiles, then enabling full trust in Settings > General > About > Certificate Trust Settings. Note iOS version-specific differences if relevant.

title: Android trust installation instructions
description: Instructions for installing as a user CA certificate. CRITICAL CAVEAT: Android apps targeting API 24+ (Android 7+) do not trust user-installed CAs by default — only system CAs. Clearly explain this limitation and which apps will/won't work. Root/Magisk workarounds are out of scope but can be mentioned.

title: Clear warnings and caveats where applicable
description: Ensure all HOWTO pages include appropriate warnings: security implications of trusting a custom root CA, the Android user CA limitation, Firefox using its own trust store, Java apps using cacerts, etc. Caveats should be prominent but not alarming.

title: Packaging and Embedding
description: Embed all static assets (HTML templates, Pico.css, JS, documentation) into the Go binary using go:embed. The binary must run without any external files except its own persistent state directory. Ensure reproducible builds.

title: Documentation
description: Project README, philosophy explanation, certificate model documentation, bootstrap flow explanation, non-goals, and 'Future Me' maintenance guide. Written for someone who last touched the project years ago.

title: Operational Polish
description: Sensible logging, clear startup messages, clear error messages in UI and API, defensive checks against accidental misuse, clean shutdown behavior. The finishing touches that make ShushTLS feel solid and trustworthy.

title: Embed static assets into the Go binary
description: Use go:embed to embed HTML templates, CSS (Pico.css), JavaScript, and any static documentation files into the binary. Define the embed directory structure (e.g. web/templates/, web/static/).

title: Embed HTML templates
description: Embed all Go html/template files. Use template inheritance (base layout + page-specific content). Templates must be parsed from embedded FS at startup.

title: Embed Pico.css
description: Vendor Pico.css into the project and embed it. Serve it from a static asset route. No CDN dependency — the binary must work on an air-gapped LAN.

title: Ensure reproducible builds
description: Pin Go version in go.mod, vendor or pin dependencies, ensure go:embed produces deterministic output. Document build instructions.

title: Ensure binary runs without external files
description: Integration check: the built binary must serve all pages, styles, and scripts without any files on disk except its state directory. Verify no runtime file-not-found errors when run from an empty directory.

title: Project README explaining philosophy and usage
description: Write a README.md covering: what ShushTLS is, why it exists, the philosophy (boring infrastructure, long-lived, low overhead), quick start guide, how it works conceptually, and explicit non-goals. Written for someone discovering the project fresh.

title: Clear explanation of root vs leaf certificates
description: Documentation (in README or separate doc) explaining the certificate model in plain language: what the root CA is, what the wildcard leaf is, why trust installation is needed, how they relate. For non-cryptographers.

title: Explicit non-goals and tradeoffs
description: Document what ShushTLS intentionally does NOT do and why. Cover: no public trust, no short-lived certs, no rotation, no revocation, no auth, no HA, no compliance. Frame as conscious decisions, not missing features.

title: Future Me documentation for maintenance
description: A 'Future Me' section or document for the operator who returns to this system after years. Cover: where state lives on disk, how to regenerate certs if needed, how to add a new device to the trust, what to do if a cert expires (in 10+ years), how to rebuild the binary.

title: Bootstrap flow explanation
description: Document the full bootstrap flow: first start (HTTP) -> initialize -> install trust -> restart -> HTTPS mode. Include a diagram or clear step numbering. Explain why the restart is required (TLS deadlock avoidance).

title: Sensible logging
description: Structured or semi-structured logging. Log startup mode (HTTP/HTTPS), port, state directory, certificate expiry dates. Use log/slog or similar. Keep it quiet in steady state — only log meaningful events.

title: Clear startup messages
description: On startup, print a clear human-readable banner: what mode (HTTP/HTTPS), what address, whether initialized, and where to access the UI. Make it obvious what's happening and what to do next.

title: Clear error messages in UI and API
description: All error responses (API JSON and UI rendered) must be clear and actionable. No raw stack traces, no cryptic codes. If something fails, explain what went wrong and what the user can do about it.

title: Defensive checks against accidental misuse
description: Guard against: double initialization, serving HTTPS without certs, running two instances on the same state directory, writing to read-only filesystem, etc. Fail early with clear messages rather than corrupting state.

title: Clean shutdown behavior
description: Handle SIGINT/SIGTERM gracefully. Shut down the HTTP(S) server with a timeout, log the shutdown, and exit cleanly. No orphaned goroutines or half-written files.

title: Optional basic auth for API
description:
Add optional HTTP Basic Auth that can be enabled after initialization via POST /api/auth. When enabled, write/sensitive endpoints require valid credentials. Read-only certificate endpoints remain unprotected so install scripts can fetch certs without credentials. Specifically:

Protected (when auth enabled):
- POST /api/initialize
- POST /api/certificates
- POST /api/auth
- GET /api/status
- GET /api/certificates/{san}?type=key (private key downloads)

Unprotected (always open):
- GET /api/ca/root.pem (root CA download)
- GET /api/certificates (cert listing)
- GET /api/certificates/{san} (cert download, not keys)

Credentials stored in state/auth.json with bcrypt-hashed passwords. Can be disabled via POST /api/auth with {"enabled": false} (while authenticated) or by deleting state/auth.json and restarting. Auth is off by default and requires initialization before it can be enabled.

title: Generate fresh certs on download instead of storing them

Consider generating a fresh leaf cert on each download rather than storing certs permanently. The CA and the SAN configuration (DNS names) are the only things that need to persist. When a user or device fetches a cert, ShushTLS issues a new one on the fly, signed by the root CA, with the current maximum validity. This eliminates cert expiry management entirely — just re-download when needed. Needs careful thought about the service cert (ShushTLS's own HTTPS cert) which also needs periodic rotation.

title: Generate fresh certs on download instead of storing them
description:
Browser-accepted TLS cert validity keeps shrinking per CA/Browser Forum ballot SC-081:

- Until 2026-03-15: max 398 days
- From  2026-03-15: max 200 days
- From  2027-03-15: max 100 days
- From  2029-03-15: max  47 days

At 47 days, manual cert management is untenable. ShushTLS should generate fresh leaf certs on each download rather than storing them permanently. The CA and the SAN configuration (DNS names) are the only things that need to persist. When a user or device fetches a cert, ShushTLS issues a new one on the fly, signed by the root CA, with the appropriate maximum validity for the current date. This eliminates cert expiry management entirely — just re-download when needed.

The code should be aware of these dates and automatically select the correct maximum validity based on the current date.

Needs careful thought about the service cert (ShushTLS's own HTTPS cert) which also needs periodic auto-rotation.

title: Bundle cert and key in a single file (e.g. zip) so pairs always match
description: Since certs are generated on the fly, there's a small race where the cert and key can be out of sync (e.g. if fetched around midnight or during rotation). Bundle the certificate and private key into a single file (e.g. zip or tar) so we always deliver a matching pair to the client.

Add -no-tls option for reverse-proxy deployment
description: When running ShushTLS behind a reverse proxy (e.g. Traefik, Caddy, nginx), the proxy typically terminates TLS. Add a flag (e.g. -no-tls) so the service runs HTTP-only and the user does not need to configure or use the built-in HTTPS listener.
